channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Germany Adopts a National Security Plan. Critics Call It ‘Weak.’
item.description: The country’s first national security strategy is an attempt to set priorities, especially since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, but hard commitments were short in supply.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany, center, along with members of his cabinet, introduced the country’s first comprehensive national security strategy on Wednesday.

item.title: Hoping to Avert Nuclear Crisis, U.S. Seeks Informal Agreement With Iran
item.description: The talks reflect a resumption of diplomacy between the United States and Iran after the collapse of negotiations to restore the 2015 nuclear deal.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley, Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, in a photograph released by state news. He said that he could endorse a deal with the United States if Iran’s nuclear infrastructure is kept intact.

item.title: Droves of Imran Khan’s Allies Defect as Military Ramps Up Crackdown
item.description: More than 100 key allies of Mr. Khan have left his party in recent weeks as Pakistan’s military tries to sideline the former leader.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood and Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Imran Khan, center, leaving after appearing in a court, in Lahore, Pakistan, last week.

item.title: Prison Sentence for José Rubén Zamora, Guatemalan Newspaper Publisher
item.description: The trial of José Rubén Zamora, the founder of a newspaper who was convicted of money laundering and sentenced to up to six years, came as critics say democracy in Guatemala is crumbling.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Jody García
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: José Rubén Zamora, the founder and publisher of elPeriódico, a leading Guatemala newspaper, has denied any wrongdoing and has vowed to appeal.

item.title: Boris Johnson Accuses Rishi Sunak of Blocking House of Lords Nominations
item.description: The former prime minister tried to elevate some lawmakers, as British leaders do when they leave office. But three didn’t make the cut, and now he’s fighting with Rishi Sunak.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Boris Johnson said it was “rubbish” that he had lobbied Rishi Sunak to overturn the way nominees to the House of Lords were vetted and approved.

item.title: Israel’s Judicial Crisis Enters New Phase After Move by Netanyahu
item.description: A bitter dispute over a planned judicial overhaul had calmed as political leaders negotiated. But talks were postponed on Wednesday, after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu moved to disrupt a vote.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel at the Knesset on Wednesday.

item.title: Russian Airstrikes Kill 6 Civilians as Kyiv’s Offensive Grinds On
item.description: A missile hit a warehouse in Odesa, killing at least three workers, while three more civilians were killed in the Donetsk region, Ukrainian officials said.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The burial service for a Ukrainian soldier who died in combat in Donetsk region.

item.title: The UK’s Phillip Schofield Scandal Explained, From TV to Parliament
item.description: The resignation of a television anchor, followed by an admission of an affair with a younger colleague, has gripped the British media for weeks. Here’s why.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Phillip Schofield was one of the most prominent hosts on Britain’s biggest ad-supported television network.

item.title: At Least 79 Die as Boat Carrying Migrants Sinks Near Greece
item.description: The disaster is the deadliest such episode off the country’s shores since the 2015 migrant crisis, and there were fears that the toll would rise. The cause was not immediately clear.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis and Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Hellenic Coastguard, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: As Cyclone Biparjoy Nears Pakistan and India, Tens of Thousands Evacuated
item.description: Tens of thousands of residents along both countries’ southern coasts were evacuated before the cyclone’s expected landfall on Thursday. Flooding remained a threat in some areas.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser, Judson Jones, Sameer Yasir and Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:description: Residents evacuating before the arrival of Cyclone Biparjoy in Jakhau, in the western state of Gujarat, India, on Wednesday.

item.title: Inside the Minds of Some Russian Soldiers
item.description: At a bar in a once-occupied Ukrainian village, dehumanizing messages on the walls were a stark reminder that the Kremlin wants to stamp out Ukraine and its culture.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Gaelle Girbes for The New York Times
item.media:description: Much of the graffiti left in the bar in the village of Velyka Komyshuvakha, Ukraine, dehumanized Ukrainians, a grim staple of warfare.

item.title: China, Hosting Mahmoud Abbas, Pushes Mediator Role With Israel
item.description: In meeting with the Palestinian leader, Mahmoud Abbas, Xi Jinping is pushing Beijing as an alternative to the U.S. for diplomatic leadership.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, welcoming Mahmoud Abbas, president of the Palestinian Authority, in Beijing. The visit is planned to last four days.

item.title: Israel Will Not Charge Soldiers Over Palestinian American Who Died
item.description: Omar Assad, 78, was found dead after being held at a building site last year by the Israeli Army. The military said the soldiers involved will be punished but not charged.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: Mourners carrying the body of Omar Assad during his funeral in the West Bank village of Jiljilya in 2022.

item.title: How South Korean Food Waste Is Turned Into Feed, Fuel or Fertilizer
item.description: When wasted food rots in landfills, it pollutes soil and water — and warms the planet. Here’s how one country keeps that from happening.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Chang W. Lee
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Boris Johnson Misled Parliament Over Covid Lockdown Parties, Report Says
item.description: The report offered a damning verdict on Boris Johnson, the former British prime minister, who quit Parliament last week.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain leaving his home in London in March.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: U.S. nuclear negotiations with Iran.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Iranian Supreme Leader Office, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, the Iranian supreme leader.

item.title: Key Environmentalists Back Biden, Despite Broken Oil Promises
item.description: Four major environmental groups are endorsing President Biden’s re-election bid, but some climate activists say his approval of drilling projects has been a betrayal.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: Environmental activists rallied outside the White House on a rainy Earth Day in April.

item.title: Man Who Questioned Gender of Girl, 9, Spurs Outrage
item.description: A track and field event in British Columbia has engendered debate about transphobia in Canada.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: A track and field meet for elementary students held last week in Kelowna, British Columbia, where a man questioned a 9-year-old girl’s gender.

item.title: Belarus Has Started Receiving Russian Nuclear Weapons, Lukashenko Says
item.description: The move would be another sign of worsening relations between Moscow and the West.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: President Vladimir Putin of Russia and President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus during their meeting in Sochi, Russia, last week.

item.title: U.S. Support for Ukraine Aid Starts to Fray After Debt Limit Deal
item.description: Spending caps set by the debt limit bill have empowered critics of U.S. aid to Ukraine, threatening the bipartisan coalition that has kept military assistance flowing to Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:description: The 3rd Separate Assault Brigade of the Armed Forces of Ukraine at the front line South of Bakhmut on Friday.

item.title: Blinken Plans to Meet With Top Chinese Officials in Beijing
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, who leaves Friday, could meet with Xi Jinping, China’s leader, during a visit he had postponed because of a Chinese spy balloon.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: The trip is one that Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken had to reschedule after canceling a planned visit in February, when a Chinese spy balloon flying over the United States caused an uproar.

item.title: The U.S. Is Paying Billions to Russia’s Nuclear Agency. Here’s Why.
item.description: Nuclear power companies rely on cheap enriched uranium made in Russia. That geopolitical dilemma is intensifying as climate change underscores the need for emissions-free energy.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.media:credit: Brian Kaiser for The New York Times
item.media:description: Uranium enrichment centrifuges at the ready in Ohio.

item.title: Ukraine’s Counteroffensive: What to Know
item.description: The Ukrainians are now on the offense. But measuring their progress is difficult this early on.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in the Donetsk region set up a rocket launcher last week.

item.title: Berlusconi’s Legacy Lives On Beyond Italy’s Borders
item.description: Silvio Berlusconi rose when political parties were weakened and carried on through a cascade of scandals. Leaders like Donald Trump and Jair Bolsonaro have had similar trajectories.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: A farewell to the former Italian prime minister Silvio Berlusconi projected on a civic building in Genoa on Monday night.

item.title: Russia Sends Navalny Associates to Prison for “Extremism”
item.description: Lilia Chanysheva and Rustem Mulyukov are the first of the jailed opposition leader’s organization to be convicted of charges related to national security since the Russian government declared his group an “extremist organization.”
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Lilia Chanysheva during a court hearing in Ufa, Russia, on Wednesday.

item.title: When Should a Former President Be Charged
item.description: What if Donald Trump were someone else?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.category: Federal Criminal Case Against Trump (Documents Case)
item.media:description: Donald Trump arriving in New Jersey yesterday.

item.title: Germany Introduces Its First National Security Strategy
item.description: The war in Ukraine has heightened Germany’s sense that it has become vulnerable to new threats, but some critics said the strategy lacks detail.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany at the European Parliament in May.

item.title: Tensions Rise Over Big Oil’s Role at COP28 Climate Talks
item.description: The hosts of the United Nations global climate summit later this year aim to give fossil fuel companies a bigger voice, despite loud objections.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.media:description: Sultan al-Jaber leads the Abu Dhabi National Oil Company as well as the COP28 climate talks coming this November.

item.title: Erdogan Says Sweden Shouldn’t Expect Turkish Support for NATO Bid
item.description: Turkey wants a tougher stance from Stockholm toward pro-Kurdish activists and members of an outlawed religious group whom Turkey considers terrorists.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in Ankara, Turkey, the capital, this month.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump at his Bedminster Golf Club, where he told supporters, “I did everything right, and they indicted me.”

item.title: Allies Pressure Biden to Hasten NATO Membership for Ukraine
item.description: Some members of the military alliance want to set a timetable for Ukraine to join, though only after the war is no longer raging.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden met with Jens Stoltenberg, NATO’s secretary general, in the Oval Office on Tuesday. The president has so far sought to maintain the status quo on a path for Ukraine to join NATO.

item.title: Russian Forces Strike Back Against Ukraine’s Counteroffensive
item.description: Russia attacked Ukrainian troops near villages in Ukraine’s south on the same day that Russian missiles killed at least 11 people and that President Vladimir V. Putin acknowledged some Russian losses.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Firefighters helping a resident at a heavily damaged residential building hit by shelling in Kryvyi Rih, in central Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Nigerian Wedding Boat Ride Ends in Tragedy, With at Least 103 Dead
item.description: The boat capsized on the Niger River at night, when many passengers were returning from a wedding party.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Ismail Alfa
item.media:description: The 2,600-mile Niger is the main river in West Africa.

item.title: Colombian Children Found in Jungle Had Been on Plane to Flee Armed Group
item.description: The father of two of the survivors said the family had feared the children would be recruited by a violent armed group.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:description: Colombian Air Force personnel giving medical attention to one of the four children who survived a plane crash in the jungle.

item.title: U.N. Monitor Aims to Cross Front Line to Inspect Ukrainian Nuclear Plant
item.description: The destruction of a hydroelectric dam last week unleashed a flood and threatened the water supply needed to cool the battle-scarred Zaporizhzhia plant.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rafael Mariano Grossi, the director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, on Tuesday in Kyiv, Ukraine. He said he was going to the plant to make a better assessment.

item.title: Yellen Says Bid to Decouple From China Would Be ‘Disastrous’
item.description: The Treasury secretary, speaking to a House committee, said trade and investment were crucial in U.S.-Chinese relations.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen testified Tuesday on Capitol Hill.

item.title: C.I.A. Told Ukraine Last Summer It Should Not Attack Nord Stream Pipelines
item.description: Dutch intelligence officials shared information with the C.I.A. in June 2022 that they had learned the Ukrainian military had been planning an operation using divers to blow up one of the pipelines.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: Explosions destroyed parts of the Nord Stream pipelines, which carry natural gas from Russia to Europe, in September.

item.title: U.S. Soldiers Injured in Syria Were Part of Commando Unit
item.description: Ten members of the Army’s elite Delta Force unit were flown to Germany for medical treatment after a helicopter accident.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Two U.S. MH-47 Chinook helicopters flying over Syria in 2021.

item.title: U.K. Woman Sentenced to Prison for Abortion in Eighth Month of Pregnancy
item.description: The case has prompted heated debate in England, with some arguing that abortion pills should not be available by mail and others maintaining that abortion should be fully decriminalized.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola

item.title: Berlusconi Seizes Italy’s Attention Even in Death
item.description: A day after Silvio Berlusconi’s death, some Italians said goodbye, others said good riddance, and many debated whether the billionaire and former prime minister did more good or bad for Italy.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo and Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: A makeshift memorial near the entrance to Villa San Martino in Arcore, where the coffin of Silvio Berlusconi was taken, near Milan, on Tuesday.

item.title: Biden Meets NATO Chief to Discuss Ukraine and Succession
item.description: Jens Stoltenberg, the secretary general of NATO, and President Biden met at the White House to prepare for a summit meeting next month in Lithuania.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden met with NATO’s secretary general, Jens Stoltenberg, at a NATO summit in Madrid last year.

item.title: As Egypt Faces Crisis, President el-Sisi Tries Talks With Opposition
item.description: The rare — and tightly constrained — outreach is a sign that President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi may be feeling the pressure of rising discontent and a sinking economy.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt launched national reconciliation talks that excluded Islamists, many liberals and discussions on anything linked to security.

item.title: New Zealand’s Public Broadcaster Investigates Pro-Russia Changes to Some Articles
item.description: A web editor for RNZ has been put on leave and the station has apologized for changes to articles by Reuters and the BBC that had been published on its website.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Marl Mitchell/New Zealand Herald, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Radio New Zealand said last week that it would investigate articles it found that contained problems.

item.title: Man Arrested After 3 Killed in Nottingham, UK Police Say
item.description: The authorities said they had arrested a 31-year-old man but did not give a motive for the attacks in central England. Two of the dead were university students.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and David Cole
item.media:credit: Jacob King/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Police officers blocking a road in Nottingham, England, on Tuesday, after three people were killed and three others wounded.

item.title: How Democrats Can Win Workers
item.description: We’re covering a new poll about the Democratic Party, Donald Trump’s court appearance and the N.B.A. finals.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers listening to President Biden as he speaks about infrastructure at the Port of Baltimore in 2021.

item.title: Thousands of Brides in India Are Abandoned by Husbands Overseas
item.description: Thousands of Indian women have been abandoned by men working overseas, leaving them trapped in their in-laws’ homes and often defrauded of dowry money.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Priyadarshini Ravichandran for The New York Times
item.media:description: A couple in wedding attire in the Indian state of Punjab in March.

item.title: Every Block Is Another Battle: Ukraine’s Latest Eastern Stand
item.description: Outnumbered, outgunned, out-tanked, Ukraine is putting up a scrappy defense of Marinka, another city near Bakhmut that is a few blocks from falling.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:description: Captain Fritz, a Ukrainian soldier who identified himself by his call sign, firing toward Russian positions near Marinka, in eastern Ukraine, in May.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: NATO air drills in Germany.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Lt. Gen. Ingo Gerhartz, second from left, of the German Air Force at the military air base in Wunstorf, Germany, on Monday.

item.title: 22 U.S. Troops Are Hurt in Helicopter ‘Mishap’ in Syria
item.description: The military provided few details about the accident, saying the troops had sustained “injuries of various degrees.”
item.dc:creator: Vivek Shankar
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: A U.S. military helicopter flying over Syria in 2020.

item.title: Cuban Government Is Responsible for Death of Oswaldo Payá, Report Says
item.description: The findings in the death of Oswaldo Payá contradict the Cuban government’s official version of what happened 11 years ago.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Frances Robles
item.category: Kennedy, Robert F, Center for Justice and Human Rights
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Oswaldo Payá in Havana, Cuba, in 2003. He was killed in a suspicious car crash in eastern Cuba that his family and supporters always believed had been caused by the government.

item.title: U.S. Lawmakers Ask White House to Punish South Africa for Supporting Russia
item.description: South Africa is accused of helping supply Russia with weapons for the Ukraine war, a charge that South Africa denies.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: The Lady R off Cape Town, South Africa, in December. Some U.S. officials say weapons were loaded onto the ship for Russia to use in Ukraine.

item.title: Ukraine Claims More Small Advances in Counteroffensive
item.description: Military analysts said it would take weeks or months to gauge the success of the attacks Ukraine mounted last week across a broad stretch of the front lines.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers preparing to patrol an area of Kherson, southern Ukraine, that was flooded by the destruction of the Kakhovka dam, on Sunday.

item.title: NATO Members’ Major Air Exercise Sends Message to Russia
item.description: More than 200 planes from 25 countries gathered in Germany for the largest-scale war games in decades, held with an eye on the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Lt. Gen. Ingo Gerhartz, second from left, of the German Air Force at the military air base in Wunstorf, Germany, on Monday.

item.title: Netanyahu Trial Gets a Hollywood Mention From a Political Rival
item.description: Yair Lapid, a former colleague and now nemesis of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, testified that he had been asked to help a wealthy film producer with a tax break.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Yair Lapid, the Israeli opposition leader, arriving to testify at the trial of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Monday.

item.title: A Saudi-China Business Conference Underscores Strengthening Ties
item.description: The kingdom hosted a lavish Arab-China business conference days after a visit from the American secretary of state, inviting companies blacklisted by the United States.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: The Saudi minister of energy, Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman, being interviewed during the 10th Arab-China Business Conference in Riyadh on Sunday.

item.title: Black Rhinos, Horns Cut Off, Lose Some of Their Gusto
item.description: New research shows a conservation strategy can disrupt the animals’ social networks.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Nuwer
item.media:description: Trimming the horn of a tranquilized female black rhino in South Africa.

item.title: Scotland’s Independence Movement Is Down, but Not Out, Analysts Say
item.description: Support for Scottish independence has dipped, but backing for Scotland remaining part of the United Kingdom is fragile, too. Nicola Sturgeon’s arrest leaves the fate of the movement in flux.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: A protest in support of Scottish Independence in Glasgow last month.
